Conference Overview

The International Conference on Virtual Reality Continuum and its Applications (VRCAI) is an ACM SIGGRAPH-sponsored conference focusing on cutting-edge innovations in virtual reality, augmented reality, mixed reality, and artificial intelligence. Since its inception in 2002, VRCAI has become an important platform for global virtual reality researchers, practitioners, and artists.

VRCAI 2025 will be held from December 13-14 in Macau, China, hosted by the Macau University of Science and Technology. The conference will bring together world-class experts and scholars for in-depth exchanges and discussions on the latest developments and applications of virtual reality continuum technologies.

We cordially invite you to submit original research papers, demonstrations, artworks, and to participate in this conference!

Conference Theme

VRCAI 2025

Reality Fusion: Virtual Reality in the Era of Metaverse and Artificial Intelligence

With the rise of the metaverse concept and the rapid development of artificial intelligence technologies, the Virtual Reality Continuum is facing unprecedented opportunities and challenges. VRCAI 2025 will focus on the core theme of "Reality Fusion," exploring how to drive innovation and application of virtual reality technologies in the era of metaverse and artificial intelligence.

This conference will particularly focus on the deep integration of artificial intelligence and virtual reality, including AI-driven content creation, intelligent interaction, and personalized immersive experiences. Through bringing together the wisdom of global researchers, we hope to jointly explore the increasingly blurred boundaries between virtual and reality, and promote the in-depth application of virtual reality continuum technologies in research, industry, and art.

WorkShop

Session on Digital Heritage in the Age of AI and the Metaverse

Digital heritage is undergoing a seismic transformation. The convergence of Artificial Intelligence (AI), immersive technologies (VR/AR/MR/XR), game engines, generative models, and interactive 3D environments has redefined how we capture, reconstruct, preserve, interpret, and engage with cultural heritage. With the rise of large language models (LLMs), multimodal AI, and the conceptual expansion of the Metaverse, we are witnessing not only technological evolution but also the reshaping of cultural memory, storytelling, and heritage interpretation.

Topic Session Invited by Industry

NVIDIA added a topic session (1 hour) which will run immediately after the Session on Digital Heritage. It will be special presentations + Q&A. This is a great opportunity to communicate with the cutting-edge of the industry

Co-host: Dr. Charles Cheung, Deputy Director, NVIDIA AI Technology Center Hong Kong, NVIDIA Corporation. AND Cliff Ho, Senior Solution Architect & Omniverse Lead, NVIDIA AI Technology Center Hong Kong, NVIDIA Corporation

Session on Video Understanding and Grounding (VUG) in the Age of AI and the Metaverse

This workshop aims to advance the frontier of vision-language understanding in video content, focusing on the critical intersection of visual perception and natural language processing in temporal media. Video grounding represents a fundamental challenge in multimodal AI, requiring models to precisely localize and understand video segments based on natural language descriptions, bridging the semantic gap between human language and visual temporal dynamics.

Session on AI-Powered Medical Image Analysis and Computer Graphics in Healthcare

This workshop explores the cutting-edge intersection of medical image processing and computer graphics, aiming to foster innovation and collaboration between clinicians, scientists, and engineers. We will delve into how advanced computational techniques are revolutionizing the way we acquire, analyze, and visualize medical data. The session will cover key topics such as the segmentation of anatomical structures from MRI/CT scans, 3D reconstruction of organs and tissues, the development of interactive surgical planning systems, and the creation of immersive educational tools using augmented and virtual reality (AR/VR). Participants will gain insights into how graphics rendering pipelines enhance the interpretation of complex medical datasets, transforming them into intuitive, high-fidelity visual models.

Conference Schedule Preview

Day 1 - December 13, 2025 (Saturday)

Opening Ceremony, Keynote Talks, and Technical Sessions

09:00-09:20
Opening Ceremony
09:20-10:05
Keynote talk
Prof. Nadia Thalmann
10:05-10:25 Tea Break
10:25-11:10
Keynote talk
Prof. Eugene Ch'ng

Title: Presence and the Current Landscape of Immersive Media

Abstract:

Sixty years of collective development in immersive media have taken the community on a journey, from the founding of early visualisation laboratories to contemporary CAVE-like installations, HMD-based systems, advanced geoscientific visualisation environments, and game-engine-driven workflows. Research emphasis has now shifted toward interaction, workflow, and content, rather than display engineering. But have we understood the structures and properties of immersive media, and how to use and extend them? The keynote highlights the concentration, growth, and decline of topics within the field, based on articles published over the past 50 years, and proposes research areas where focus should be directed in the next decade.

Bio:

Professor Eugene Ch'ng FSA is Dean of the School of Culture and Creativity at Beijing Normal-Hong Kong Baptist University. He is the founding Director of the Centre for Computational Culture and Heritage and the NVIDIA Deep Learning Institute (DLI). A distinguished scholar in the interdisciplinary field of digital culture and heritage and a recognised expert in XR technologies, he currently serves as Editor-in-Chief of PRESENCE: Virtual and Augmented Reality (MIT Press). Professor Ch'ng has led pioneering centres, including the IBM Visual and Spatial Technology Centre and the Digital Humanities Hub at the University of Birmingham (2011-2013), and the NVIDIA Joint Lab on Mixed Reality at the University of Nottingham Ningbo China (2016-2023), all as founding director. His work has been instrumental in advancing digital technologies for cultural heritage, attracting major funding from the UK, Europe, and China. He has published over 145 peer-reviewed articles and two influential edited volumes, Visual Heritage in the Digital Age and Visual Heritage: Digital Approaches in Heritage Science, which have shaped global discourse on scientific and digital methods in cultural heritage. He has been listed among the world's top 2% most-cited scientists by Stanford University.

11:10-11:55
Keynote talk
Prof. Haining Liang

Title: Beyond Touch: Reconceptualizing Interaction in the Era of Spatial Interfaces

Abstract:

Extended reality (XR) systems are transforming how people interact with digital content. As a disruptive, emerging technology, XR provides an ideal platform to reimagine next-generation interfaces that emphasize natural and intuitive spatial interactions. Just as touch-enabled mobile devices have changed and enriched our understanding of digital interfaces, XR compels us to rethink the nature of these interfaces. Our conception of such interfaces is shifting from digital content displayed in bounded windows that exist outside us to virtual spaces that make us feel as if we are living within them. This transition is enabled by XR’s immersive experiences, which are then facilitated by interactions that extend beyond touch-based methods to include other spatial modalities aligned with the rich and open nature of people’s engagement with our physical world. In this talk, I will explore how XR has opened new possibilities to reimagine our interaction with digital content. I will also describe several innovative techniques and interfaces for XR systems that we have developed to enhance user experience and task performance. These techniques and interfaces utilize the various input modalities available in XR systems, leveraging people's spatial abilities, to create more efficient and user-friendly interactions that, in turn, foster a stronger sense of integration with both the physical and virtual worlds.

Bio:

Hai-Ning Liang is an Associate Professor within the Computational Media and Arts Thrust, the Hong Kong University of Science and Technology (Guangzhou). He was previously a Full Professor in the Department of Computing at Xi'an Jiaotong-Liverpool University (XJTLU), where he served as its founding Head (2019-2023) and the Deputy Director of the Suzhou Municipal Key Lab for Intelligent Virtual Engineering and the XJTLU Virtual Engineering Centre. He received his PhD in computer science from Western University in Canada. His research focuses on the design and evaluation of novel interactions and applications for virtual and mixed reality, gaming, and visualization technologies. He has published over 300 papers on these topics, which have accumulated over 6200 citations and an h-index of 44. His papers have won numerous awards and prestigious recognitions, including the 2024 IEEE ICDM 10-year Highest-Impact Paper Award, 2025 IEEE ToG Outstanding Paper Award (Nomination), Best Paper Award (Honorable Mention) at ACM ISS’24, and Best Paper (Honorary Mention) at IEEE VR’24. He serves on the editorial board of several journals and the organization committees of some of the top-ranked conferences in his research areas, including IEEE VR and IEEE ISMAR.

11:25-12:30 Lunch Break
14:00-16:00
Session B: Main Track - Human-Computer Interaction and User Experience (Room B102)
14:00-16:00
Session D: Workshop-1 - Digital Heritage in the Age of AI and the Metaverse (Room B103)
NVIDIA talks. Dr Ginny Wong, Senior Scientist, NVIDIA AI Technology Center, NVIDIA and Dr Charles Cheung, Deputy Director, NVIDIA AI Technology Center, NVIDIA

Title: Accelerating Generative AI and Multi-Agent Systems with NVIDIA DGX Spark and NIM

Abstract:

This session explores how the NVIDIA DGX Spark ecosystem can empower next-generation generative AI and intelligent multi-agent applications. Participants will be introduced to leveraging DGX Spark as a flexible, high-performance remote resource, supporting distributed AI workloads and rapid development cycles. The session will provide technical guidance and live demonstrations focused on inference using TensorRT-LLM and NVIDIA NIM (NVIDIA Inference Microservices).

Pre-requisites:

Basic understanding of AI and machine learning concepts.Familiarity with Python programming and common data science workflows.Experience with AI inference or chatbot/video agent development will enhance learning but is not necessary for participation.

Day 2 - December 14, 2025 (Sunday)

Keynote Talks, Workshops, Technical Sessions and Closing Ceremony

09:00-09:45
Keynote talk
Prof. Bin Sheng

Title:

Abstract:

Bio:

Bin Sheng obtained his Ph.D. degree in Computer Science and Engineering from The Chinese University of Hong Kong in 2011. He currently serves as a Full Professor at the Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Shanghai Jiao Tong University. His research interests span virtual reality, machine learning, and medical data analysis. His work has been published in top-tier journals, including Nature Medicine, Nature Communications, IEEE Transactions on Pattern Analysis and Machine Intelligence (TPAMI), IEEE Transactions on Visualization and Computer Graphics (TVCG), and International Journal of Computer Vision (IJCV). Dr. Sheng holds editorial roles as Managing Editor of The Visual Computer and Associate Editor of the Journal of Virtual Reality and Intelligent Hardware. He has also contributed significantly to conference organization, serving as Program Co-Chair of Computer Graphics International (CGI) from 2020 to 2022, and Conference Co-Chair of CGI (2023–2024) and CASA 2024. Additionally, he was AI Challenge Co-Chair for DeepDRiD (ISBI 2020), DRAC (MICCAI 2022), and MMAC (MICCAI 2023). In recognition of his contributions, he received the Outstanding Contribution Award from the Computer Graphics Society in 2023.

09:45-10:30
Keynote talk
Prof. Yuhan Ji

Title: Research on the Impact of Social Presence of Embodied AI Agents in Immersive Cultural Learning

Bio:

Yuhan Ji, Ph.D., is an Assistant Professor and Associate Program Director of Master of Arts in FTNM at Beijing Normal - Hong Kong Baptist University. He earned his Ph.D. in Computer Science and Applications from the University of California, Santa Cruz, USA, and holds additional degrees in Games and Playable Media, Software Engineering, and Geographic Information System. Dr. Ji has made significant contributions to academic literature with publications such as Ji, Y., Luo, Y., Chen, R. (2025). CleanScape: An Augmented Reality Intervention for Assessing and Treating Contamination-Based Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder. PRESENCE: Virtual and Augmented Reality, 1-15.; Ji, Y., Liang, Y., Yang, Z., AI, N. (2023). SW-Net: A novel few-shot learning approach for disease subtype prediction. Biocell, 47(3), 569-579.; and Ji, Y. (2025). Processing 创意编程入门: 从编程原理到项目案例. Tsinghua University Press.. In addition to his academic work, Dr. Ji has been invol ved in various research projects including Co-Investigator of a Research Project titled 'Digital Studies of Ancient Bronze Bells: Sound, Form, and Re-creation'. Responsible for developing AR/VR interactive applications for learning and expe riencing Ancient Bronze Bells.

Conference Venue

ACM SIGGRAPH VRCAI 2025 will be held at Macau University of Science and Technology (MUST), located in Taipa, Macau, China.

Macau University of Science and Technology (MUST)

Address: Avenida Wai Long, Taipa, Macau, China

Building: Block O, Academic Building

GPS Coordinates: 22.1559° N, 113.5673° E

Transportation: The university is approximately 15 minutes from Macau International Airport and easily accessible by taxi, bus, or shuttle services.

For more details about the venue, accommodation options, and transportation, please visit our Venue page.
